awd_titl_txt: A Chemo-Thermo-Mechanics Theory: Application to High-Temperature Thermal Barrier Coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
Thermal barrier coatings are applied to superalloy turbine blades to provide thermal insulation and oxidation protection. A typical coating consists of an
 oxide/metal bilayer: the outer oxide layer (top-coat) imparts thermal insulation, while the metallic layer (bond-coat) affords oxidation protection through the formation of a thermally-grown-oxide at elevated temperatures. Bond-coat oxidation is the primary cause of coating failure. The goal of this research is to   develop a simulation-based design capability to predict the stability and durability of thermal barrier coatings. The specific aims are to: (i) Develop a continuum-level chemo-thermo-mechanics theory for modeling the coupled diffusion-oxidation-deformation and degradation of coating systems. (ii) Numerically implement the theory and develop a robust simulation-based capability for predicting coating   performance. (iii) Conduct an experimental research program to validate the predictive capabilities of the theory and simulation-based design capability.
  
Over the past 40 years, natural-gas-combined-cycle turbine-technology has evolved to dominate large scale power generation. The main technological challenges for this technology going into the future are: (i) to improve the combustion design to reduce emissions, while raising firing temperatures beyond 1430°C (the current standard); (ii) to extend operation time between maintenance intervals; and (iii) to further improve the reliability of these complex systems. The stability and durability of single-crystal turbine blades and thermal barrier coatings in such advanced applications is not very well understood or modeled. This research will provide a theoretical basis for life-prediction and performance improvement of thermal barrier coatings in such severe environments.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Thermal barrier coatings (TBCs)  are applied to superalloy turbine blades to provide  thermal insulation and oxidation protection.  A TBC consists of an oxide/metal bilayer: the outer ceramic oxide layer  (top-coat)  imparts thermal insulation, while the metallic layer (bond-coat)  affords oxidation protection through the formation of a   thermally-grown-oxide  (TGO) at elevated temperatures.  One of the problems limiting the use of TBCs is their long-term durability.  After a certain amount of service life the coatings usually fail by spallation; failure often occurs either by debonding at the top-coat/TGO interface.  Bond-coat oxidation is the primary cause of TBC failure. Our overall aims in this project were to obtain a fundamental understanding of the behavior of thermal barrier coatings and their oxidation and hot corrosion characteristics, and  to develop a simulation-based design capability  to predict the performance (stability and durability)  of  thermal barrier coatings on turbine blades. The major outcomes of our research are: (a) We have formulated a continuum-level chemo-thermo-mechanically coupled theory  for oxidation of high-temperature alloys. (b) We have numerically implemented our coupled theory in  a  finite-element program. (c) We have calibrated the material parameters in our theory for  an FeCrAlY heat-resistant alloy. (d) Using our theory we have simulated the high-temperature oxidation of  thin sheets of FeCrAlY, and shown that our theory is capable of reproducing  the oxide thickness evolution with time at different temperatures, the  permanent  extensional changes in dimensions   of  the  base material being oxidized,   as well as    the development of large compressive residual stresses in the  protective  surface oxide which forms.  (e) Next, since undulations in the growing TGO layer in a TBC give rise to   normal stresses  at the interface between the ceramic top-coat and the TGO,  and these lead  to local decohesion and eventual spalling  of the top-coat, we  have numerically studied the growth and shape-distortion of the thermally-grown-oxide, and the  induced decohesion of the top-coat  from  the bond-coat. We  have accounted for the experimentally-observed creep response of the top-coat at high temperatures.  The  interface between the TGO and the top-coat was modeled using  a   cohesive-zone  methodology based on an interface   traction-separation model. These material-modeling features were implemented  in the commercial finite element package  ABAQUS to carry out our simulation studies. Using this numerical capability we have conducted  parametric studies of top-coat  decohesion   by varying the geometry of the initial sinusoidal undulation at the top-coat/bond-coat interface.  (f) We have also developed a new experimental-plus-simulation-based approach to determine the relevant material parameters appearing in  a traction-separation-type law for modeling delamination failures in TBCs. This completed research effort provides a fundamental methodology  for TBC design, life prediction,  and failure analysis. The following published journal papers summarize the outcomes of our research on TBCs:

  1. Loeffel, K., and Anand, L., 2011.  A chemo-thermo-mechanically coupled theory for elastic-viscoplastic deformation, diffusion, and volumetric swelling due to a chemical reaction. International Journal of Plasticity 27, 1409-1431.
  2. Loeffel, K., Anand, L., Gasem, Z.M., 2013. On modeling the oxidation of high-temperature alloys. Acta Materialia 61, 399-424.
  3. Al-Athel, K., Loeffel, K., Liu, H., and Anand, L., 2013. Modeling decohesion of a top-coat from a thermally-growing oxide in a thermal barrier coating. Surface and Coatings Technology 222, 68-78.
  4. Di Leo, C.V., Luk-Cyr J.,  Loeffel, K., Al-Athel A., Anand, L., 2014. A new methodology for characterizing traction-separation relations for  interfacial delamination of thermal barrier coatings. Acta Materialia 71, 306-318.

Of broader impact is the application of our research to other clean energy technologies, such as Li-ion batteries. During the course of our research we saw an opportunity to extend our theory and computational procedures and apply them to study the closely related problem of coupled diffusion-deformation-failure response of Li-ion battery electrode materials in which  diffusion induced microcracks,  and  the formation of solid electrolyte interphase are the predominant degradation mechanisms which cause capacity fade and  a rise in the impedance of the cell. The following published journal papers summarize the outcomes of our research on Li-ion electrode materials:

  1. Anand, L., 2012.  A Cahn-Hilliard-type theory for species diffusion coupled with large elastic-plastic deformations. Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids 60, 1983-2002.
  2. Di Leo, C.V., Rejovitzky, E., Anand, L., 2014.  A Cahn-Hilliard-type phase-field theory for species diffusion coupled with large elastic deformations: application to phase-separating Li-ion electrode materials. Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids 70, 1-29.
  3. Rejovitzky, E., Di Leo, C.V.,  Anand, L., 2015. A theory and a simulation capability for the growth of a solid electrolyte interphase layer at an anode particle in a Li-ion battery. Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids 78, 210-230.
  4. Di Leo, C.V.,  Rejovitzky, E., Anand, L., 2015. Diffusion-deformation theory for amorphous silicon anodes: the role of plastic deformation on electrochemical performance.International Journal of Solids and Structures  67-68,  283-296.

Last Modified: 09/01/2016
Modified by: Lallit Anand
por.por_txt_cntn:
Thermal barrier coatings (TBCs)  are applied to superalloy turbine blades to provide  thermal insulation and oxidation protection.  A TBC consists of an oxide/metal bilayer: the outer ceramic oxide layer  (top-coat)  imparts thermal insulation, while the metallic layer (bond-coat)  affords oxidation protection through the formation of a   thermally-grown-oxide  (TGO) at elevated temperatures.  One of the problems limiting the use of TBCs is their long-term durability.  After a certain amount of service life the coatings usually fail by spallation; failure often occurs either by debonding at the top-coat/TGO interface.  Bond-coat oxidation is the primary cause of TBC failure. Our overall aims in this project were to obtain a fundamental understanding of the behavior of thermal barrier coatings and their oxidation and hot corrosion characteristics, and  to develop a simulation-based design capability  to predict the performance (stability and durability)  of  thermal barrier coatings on turbine blades. The major outcomes of our research are: (a) We have formulated a continuum-level chemo-thermo-mechanically coupled theory  for oxidation of high-temperature alloys. (b) We have numerically implemented our coupled theory in  a  finite-element program. (c) We have calibrated the material parameters in our theory for  an FeCrAlY heat-resistant alloy. (d) Using our theory we have simulated the high-temperature oxidation of  thin sheets of FeCrAlY, and shown that our theory is capable of reproducing  the oxide thickness evolution with time at different temperatures, the  permanent  extensional changes in dimensions   of  the  base material being oxidized,   as well as    the development of large compressive residual stresses in the  protective  surface oxide which forms.  (e) Next, since undulations in the growing TGO layer in a TBC give rise to   normal stresses  at the interface between the ceramic top-coat and the TGO,  and these lead  to local decohesion and eventual spalling  of the top-coat, we  have numerically studied the growth and shape-distortion of the thermally-grown-oxide, and the  induced decohesion of the top-coat  from  the bond-coat. We  have accounted for the experimentally-observed creep response of the top-coat at high temperatures.  The  interface between the TGO and the top-coat was modeled using  a   cohesive-zone  methodology based on an interface   traction-separation model. These material-modeling features were implemented  in the commercial finite element package  ABAQUS to carry out our simulation studies. Using this numerical capability we have conducted  parametric studies of top-coat  decohesion   by varying the geometry of the initial sinusoidal undulation at the top-coat/bond-coat interface.  (f) We have also developed a new experimental-plus-simulation-based approach to determine the relevant material parameters appearing in  a traction-separation-type law for modeling delamination failures in TBCs. This completed research effort provides a fundamental methodology  for TBC design, life prediction,  and failure analysis. The following published journal papers summarize the outcomes of our research on TBCs:

Loeffel, K., and Anand, L., 2011.  A      chemo-thermo-mechanically coupled theory for elastic-viscoplastic      deformation, diffusion, and volumetric swelling due to a chemical      reaction. International Journal of Plasticity 27, 1409-1431.
Loeffel, K., Anand, L., Gasem, Z.M., 2013. On modeling      the oxidation of high-temperature alloys. Acta Materialia 61, 399-424.
Al-Athel, K., Loeffel, K., Liu, H., and Anand, L.,      2013. Modeling decohesion of a top-coat from a thermally-growing oxide in      a thermal barrier coating. Surface and Coatings Technology 222, 68-78.
Di Leo, C.V., Luk-Cyr J.,  Loeffel, K., Al-Athel      A., Anand, L., 2014. A new methodology for characterizing      traction-separation relations for  interfacial delamination of      thermal barrier coatings. Acta Materialia 71, 306-318.


Of broader impact is the application of our research to other clean energy technologies, such as Li-ion batteries. During the course of our research we saw an opportunity to extend our theory and computational procedures and apply them to study the closely related problem of coupled diffusion-deformation-failure response of Li-ion battery electrode materials in which  diffusion induced microcracks,  and  the formation of solid electrolyte interphase are the predominant degradation mechanisms which cause capacity fade and  a rise in the impedance of the cell. The following published journal papers summarize the outcomes of our research on Li-ion electrode materials:

Anand, L., 2012.  A Cahn-Hilliard-type theory for      species diffusion coupled with large elastic-plastic deformations. Journal      of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids 60, 1983-2002.
Di Leo, C.V., Rejovitzky, E., Anand, L., 2014.  A      Cahn-Hilliard-type phase-field theory for species diffusion coupled with      large elastic deformations: application to phase-separating Li-ion      electrode materials. Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids 70,      1-29.
Rejovitzky, E., Di Leo, C.V.,  Anand, L., 2015. A      theory and a simulation capability for the growth of a solid electrolyte      interphase layer at an anode particle in a Li-ion battery. Journal of the      Mechanics and Physics of Solids 78, 210-230.
Di Leo, C.V.,  Rejovitzky, E., Anand, L., 2015.      Diffusion-deformation theory for amorphous silicon anodes: the role of plastic      deformation on electrochemical performance.International Journal of Solids      and Structures  67-68,  283-296.
